* Export build-sysprobe-binary task

* Do not uncompress generated artifacts in /tmp/system-probe
fix TestGetHostInfo (#20377)
Remove lock on Pulumi commands (#20367)
Add do not merge at the end of the pipeline (#20389)
[DBMON-2461] Bump up go-sqllexer to support collecting procedure names (#20341)

Add duplicated-imports linter rule and fix it (#20154)

Add duplicated-imports linter rule and fix it

[CWS] remove easyjson dep for windows (#20344)

* [CWS] remove easyjson dep for windows

* fix macos

Deploy new buildimages with default configuration for curl, wget and awscli (#20388)

And few modification for invoke task
[Serverless] Fix KMS key detection (#20382)

fix dns stat test (#20347)

* fix dns stat test

* remove build dir

* remove debug
[CWS/CSPM] handle error in/from `NewRuleFilterModel` (#20395)

[ASCII-849] Move few components to the new file hierarchy. (#20372)

* Move few components to the new file hierarchy.
- Rename package serverDebug to serverdebug (Revive)
- Rename sime types something to somethingImpl to avoid conflict with package name

* Fix windows build

* rename pacakge  impl  to componentimpl

* Add missing file

* Fix code owner

* Fix unit tests:
- Revert case for serverdebug (serverdebug -> serverDebug) as this lead to issue on the CI
- Fix Windows build
- Fix Linux build
- Fix revive issues
    - "should use bytes.Equal" gosimple
    - Use NewIconFromHICONForDPI instead of NewIconFromHICON

* Fix component linter issue
Add install script logs output (#20405)

cmd/serverless: move to github.com/aws/aws-sdk-go-v2 (#20221)

* cmd/serverless: move from github.com/aws/aws-sdk-go to github.com/aws/aws-sdk-go-v2

* fix go.mod go.sum conflicts

* tidy

---------

Co-authored-by: Maxime David <maxime.david@datadoghq.com>

collect boot logs as artifacts for KMT (#20362)

* collect boot logs as artifacts for KMT

* remove useless cat

Co-authored-by: Nicolas Schweitzer <nicolas.schweitzer@datadoghq.com>

* Use released runner image

* Fix hash of test-infra-definitions

---------

Co-authored-by: Nicolas Schweitzer <nicolas.schweitzer@datadoghq.com>

usm: tests: Fixed protocol classification flakiness (#20399)

* usm: tests: Fixed protocol classification flakiness

* Fixed CR comments

[oracle] Emit query metrics with zero executions (DBMON-2963) (#20386)

* obfuscator tests added

* zero executions

* Revert "obfuscator tests added"

This reverts commit 42f464102655f5ea88ce68867858c630b09af294.

[Component][ASCII-849]: Use new file organisation component (#20339)

* Use new file organisation component

* Make it consistent with https://github.com/DataDog/datadog-agent/pull/20372
releasenotes: mention openssl update (#20387)

[RC-1313] Add integration allow list (#20318)

* Add integration allow list

* Add tests

* Address review

## Bloop Bleep... Dogbot Here

Regression Detector Results

Run ID: f3378115-2225-444d-98d8-48242817c7b4
Baseline: ad028547ddf6bd81dbbd3b6635638a6ae7c18a15
Comparison: e6d63b71bc6260d072ea1fb72cc8df55985fa233
Total datadog-agent CPUs: 7

Explanation

A regression test is an integrated performance test for datadog-agent in a repeatable rig, with varying configuration for datadog-agent. What follows is a statistical summary of a brief datadog-agent run for each configuration across SHAs given above. The goal of these tests are to determine quickly if datadog-agent performance is changed and to what degree by a pull request.

Because a target's optimization goal performance in each experiment will vary somewhat each time it is run, we can only estimate mean differences in optimization goal relative to the baseline target. We express these differences as a percentage change relative to the baseline target, denoted "Δ mean %". These estimates are made to a precision that balances accuracy and cost control. We represent this precision as a 90.00% confidence interval denoted "Δ mean % CI": there is a 90.00% chance that the true value of "Δ mean %" is in that interval.

We decide whether a change in performance is a "regression" -- a change worth investigating further -- if both of the following two criteria are true:

  1. The estimated |Δ mean %| ≥ 5.00%. This criterion intends to answer the question "Does the estimated change in mean optimization goal performance have a meaningful impact on your customers?". We assume that when |Δ mean %| < 5.00%, the impact on your customers is not meaningful. We also assume that a performance change in optimization goal is worth investigating whether it is an increase or decrease, so long as the magnitude of the change is sufficiently large.

  2. Zero is not in the 90.00% confidence interval "Δ mean % CI" about "Δ mean %". This statement is equivalent to saying that there is at least a 90.00% chance that the mean difference in optimization goal is not zero. This criterion intends to answer the question, "Is there a statistically significant difference in mean optimization goal performance?". It also means there is no more than a 10.00% chance this criterion reports a statistically significant difference when the true difference in mean optimization goal is zero -- a "false positive". We assume you are willing to accept a 10.00% chance of inaccurately detecting a change in performance when no true difference exists.

The table below, if present, lists those experiments that have experienced a statistically significant change in mean optimization goal performance between baseline and comparison SHAs with 90.00% confidence OR have been detected as newly erratic. Negative values of "Δ mean %" mean that baseline is faster, whereas positive values of "Δ mean %" mean that comparison is faster. Results that do not exhibit more than a ±5.00% change in their mean optimization goal are discarded. An experiment is erratic if its coefficient of variation is greater than 0.1. The abbreviated table will be omitted if no interesting change is observed.

No interesting changes in experiment optimization goals with confidence ≥ 90.00% and |Δ mean %| ≥ 5.00%.

### What does this PR do?

The PR is moving the management step-by-step, thus it is recommended to review the change commit by a commit.

## Bloop Bleep... Dogbot Here

Regression Detector Results

Run ID: 02f3bb7b-e547-4d24-804f-ebfc10264e8f
Baseline: d18db9947e261b535fe09f86bb8bb8bd32ef816b
Comparison: 55b1eb910d458fcddbe9bce8b2b6e2f2d5218675
Total datadog-agent CPUs: 7

Explanation

A regression test is an integrated performance test for datadog-agent in a repeatable rig, with varying configuration for datadog-agent. What follows is a statistical summary of a brief datadog-agent run for each configuration across SHAs given above. The goal of these tests are to determine quickly if datadog-agent performance is changed and to what degree by a pull request.

Because a target's optimization goal performance in each experiment will vary somewhat each time it is run, we can only estimate mean differences in optimization goal relative to the baseline target. We express these differences as a percentage change relative to the baseline target, denoted "Δ mean %". These estimates are made to a precision that balances accuracy and cost control. We represent this precision as a 90.00% confidence interval denoted "Δ mean % CI": there is a 90.00% chance that the true value of "Δ mean %" is in that interval.

We decide whether a change in performance is a "regression" -- a change worth investigating further -- if both of the following two criteria are true:

  1. The estimated |Δ mean %| ≥ 5.00%. This criterion intends to answer the question "Does the estimated change in mean optimization goal performance have a meaningful impact on your customers?". We assume that when |Δ mean %| < 5.00%, the impact on your customers is not meaningful. We also assume that a performance change in optimization goal is worth investigating whether it is an increase or decrease, so long as the magnitude of the change is sufficiently large.

  2. Zero is not in the 90.00% confidence interval "Δ mean % CI" about "Δ mean %". This statement is equivalent to saying that there is at least a 90.00% chance that the mean difference in optimization goal is not zero. This criterion intends to answer the question, "Is there a statistically significant difference in mean optimization goal performance?". It also means there is no more than a 10.00% chance this criterion reports a statistically significant difference when the true difference in mean optimization goal is zero -- a "false positive". We assume you are willing to accept a 10.00% chance of inaccurately detecting a change in performance when no true difference exists.

The table below, if present, lists those experiments that have experienced a statistically significant change in mean optimization goal performance between baseline and comparison SHAs with 90.00% confidence OR have been detected as newly erratic. Negative values of "Δ mean %" mean that baseline is faster, whereas positive values of "Δ mean %" mean that comparison is faster. Results that do not exhibit more than a ±5.00% change in their mean optimization goal are discarded. An experiment is erratic if its coefficient of variation is greater than 0.1. The abbreviated table will be omitted if no interesting change is observed.

No interesting changes in experiment optimization goals with confidence ≥ 90.00% and |Δ mean %| ≥ 5.00%.

pull_request.title: Containers new e2e tests code refactoring
pull_request.body:
### What does this PR do?

* Add a `--keep-stacks` parameter on the `inv new-e2e-tests.run …` command to skip the stacks deletion at the end of the tests and be able to re-use them at next run.
* Use “named arguments” for `testMetric`.
  It has two parts: a `filter` section to specify the filtering options to select which series we want to inspect and an `expect` section to specify the expected properties of the selected series.
  For ex., in order to ensure that a metric named `nginx.net.request_per_s` tagged with `kube_namespace:workload-nginx` has all the following tags: `container_id`, `image_id`…, instead of writing:
```go
suite.testMetric("nginx.net.request_per_s",
  []string{
    "kube_namespace:workload-nginx",
  },
  []*regexp.Regexp{
    regexp.MustCompile(`^container_id:.*`),
    regexp.MustCompile(`^image_id:.*$`),
    …
  },
)
```
  we can now write:
```go
suite.testMetric(&testMetricArgs{
  filter: testMetricFilterArgs{
    name: "nginx.net.request_per_s",
    tags: []string{
      "kube_namespace:workload-nginx",
    },
  },
  expect: testMetricExpectArgs{
    tags: &[]string{
      `^container_id:.*$`,
      `^image_id:.*$`,
      …
    },
  },
})
```
* Add the possibility to assert not only tags but also values on metrics.
* Some other code refactoring.

### Motivation

Structure a little bit more the code base.

### Additional Notes

### Possible Drawbacks / Trade-offs

### Describe how to test/QA your changes

Check the e2e tests.
By default pulumi stacks must still be deleted.
`--keep-stacks` must prevent the deletion.

Ex. in the CI:
* [`TestECSSuite`](https://gitlab.ddbuild.io/DataDog/datadog-agent/-/jobs/357093535)
* [`TestEKSSuite`](https://gitlab.ddbuild.io/DataDog/datadog-agent/-/jobs/357093534)
* [`TestKindSuite`](https://gitlab.ddbuild.io/DataDog/datadog-agent/-/jobs/357093533)

  during the review but the signing off is to be done by the reviewer(s).

pull_request.title: Containers new e2e tests code refactoring
pull_request.body:
### What does this PR do?

* Add a `--keep-stacks` parameter on the `inv new-e2e-tests.run …` command to skip the stacks deletion at the end of the tests and be able to re-use them at next run.
* Use “named arguments” for `testMetric`.
  It has two parts: a `filter` section to specify the filtering options to select which series we want to inspect and an `expect` section to specify the expected properties of the selected series.
  For ex., in order to ensure that a metric named `nginx.net.request_per_s` tagged with `kube_namespace:workload-nginx` has all the following tags: `container_id`, `image_id`…, instead of writing:
```go
suite.testMetric("nginx.net.request_per_s",
  []string{
    "kube_namespace:workload-nginx",
  },
  []*regexp.Regexp{
    regexp.MustCompile(`^container_id:.*`),
    regexp.MustCompile(`^image_id:.*$`),
    …
  },
)
```
  we can now write:
```go
suite.testMetric(&testMetricArgs{
  filter: testMetricFilterArgs{
    name: "nginx.net.request_per_s",
    tags: []string{
      "kube_namespace:workload-nginx",
    },
  },
  expect: testMetricExpectArgs{
    tags: &[]string{
      `^container_id:.*$`,
      `^image_id:.*$`,
      …
    },
  },
})
```
* Add the possibility to assert not only tags but also values on metrics.
* Some other code refactoring.

### Motivation

Structure a little bit more the code base.

### Additional Notes

### Possible Drawbacks / Trade-offs

### Describe how to test/QA your changes

Check the e2e tests.
By default pulumi stacks must still be deleted.
`--keep-stacks` must prevent the deletion.

comment.body:
There was a non-prioritised plan to have a suite for EKS and ECS too, if the need raised. It wraps all the boilerplate of tearing up and down the stack, plus adds some options - dev mode, skip delete on failure, stack name. 

The difference between dev mode and skip delete on failure is that the first always keeps the infra, the latter keeps it only on failure, for investigation. 

We can discuss about having one for ECS and EKS, these three top params can be shared !

pull_request.title: [NDM] Configurable Netflow additional fields collection
pull_request.body:
<!--
* New contributors are highly encouraged to read our
  [CONTRIBUTING](/CONTRIBUTING.md) documentation.
* The pull request:
  * Should only fix one issue or add one feature at a time.
  * Must update the test suite for the relevant functionality.
  * Should pass all status checks before being reviewed or merged.
* Commit titles should be prefixed with general area of pull request's change.

-->
### What does this PR do?

<!--
* A brief description of the change being made with this pull request.
* If the description here cannot be expressed in a succinct form, consider
  opening multiple pull requests instead of a single one.
-->

This PR implements configurable field collection for Netflow v9 / IPFIX.
Additional fields can be collected by using the following config for example :
```yaml
  netflow:
    enabled: true
    listeners:
      - flow_type: netflow9 # or ipfix
        mapping:
```

pull_request.body:

* Commit titles should be prefixed with general area of pull request's change.

-->
### What does this PR do?

<!--
* A brief description of the change being made with this pull request.
* If the description here cannot be expressed in a succinct form, consider
  opening multiple pull requests instead of a single one.
-->

This PR implements configurable field collection for Netflow v9 / IPFIX.
Additional fields can be collected by using the following config for example :
```yaml
  netflow:
    enabled: true
    listeners:
      - flow_type: netflow9 # or ipfix
        mapping:
          - field: 40000 # Field type
            destination: "aaa_username" # Will be queryable in datadog through this name, e.g. @aaa_username
            type: "string" # string, varint or bytes
          - field: 8
            destination: "destination.port"
            type: "varint"
          - field: 32
            destination: "icmp_type"
            type: "bytes"
```
